modules.description: Converts primitive values and structured data into a unified type, supporting booleans, integers, floats, strings, options, lists, and tuples. Accepts custom conversion functions for nested structures. Used to serialize heterogeneous data into a consistent format for logging or transmission.

The module provides string creation, transformation, and analysis through character-level operations, substring manipulation, and iteration functions (fold, map, filter), working with strings and bytes. It includes low-level byte and UTF encoding/decoding, integer extraction in different endianness, and hashing, enabling efficient binary data processing and tasks like network protocol parsing or file format manipulation.

Processes strings and bytes with character-level operations, substring handling, and iteration functions, supporting encoding/decoding, endianness conversion, and hashing for efficient binary data manipulation. Provides functions for transforming, analyzing, and extracting data from raw byte sequences. Examples include parsing network packets, extracting integers from binary buffers, and generating hashes for data validation.

Provides functions to control logging behavior such as retrieving the debug level, color setting, line width, and indentation. Operates with string inputs and a result type that tracks success or failure. Used to format and output log messages with customizable styling and structure.

Converts primitive values and structured data into a unified type, supporting booleans, integers, floats, strings, options, lists, and tuples. Accepts custom conversion functions for nested structures. Used to serialize heterogeneous data into a consistent format for logging or transmission.

Provides functions to parse and generate documentation comments in OCaml, supporting extraction of tags and formatting of structured output. Operates on source code tokens and abstract syntax tree nodes. Used to automate documentation generation from inline comments in library modules.

Transforms a variety of data types—including booleans, integers, floats, strings, options, lists, and tuples—into a uniform representation, enabling consistent handling of complex, nested structures through customizable conversion logic. Key operations include encoding values into a standardized format and decoding them back with type preservation. This allows for reliable data serialization, logging, or communication between systems. For example, it can convert a list of optional integers into a structured log entry or transmit a nested tuple across a network.
